answer_html: We plug this value of t back into the equation of the line to get that the point on the line that intersects the plane is (1,1,0).
answer_latex:
We plug this value of \emph{t} back
into the equation of the line to get that the point on the line that
intersects the plane is (1,1,0).
hints_html:
Write the equation of the line as three separate equations.

Each equation for the line depends on a single variable, t. How can we use the last equation to determine t?
hints_latex: Write the equation of the line as three separate equations.

Each equation for the line depends on a single variable, t. How can we
use the last equation to determine t?
hints_raw:
Write the equation of the line as three separate equations.
Each equation for the line depends on a single variable, t.  How can we use the last equation to determine t?
question: A 18
sols_html:
The equation of the line is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}=(1,1,0)+t(1,0,-2)\end{aligned}\]

where \(\mathbf{x}=(x,y,z)\). We can write the line as three separate equations

\[\begin{aligned} x&=1+t\\ y&=1\\ z&=-2t.\end{aligned}\]

If we use this for the equation of the plane, we get

\[\begin{aligned} x+y+z&=2\\ 1+t+1-2t&=2\\ -t&=0\end{aligned}\]

and therefore we conclude that t=0. We plug this value of t back into the equation of the line to get that the point on the line that intersects the plane is (1,1,0).
sols_raw:
The equation of the line is

:<math>
\mathbf{x}=(1,1,0)+t(1,0,-2)
</math>

where <math>\mathbf{x}=(x,y,z)</math>.  We can write the line as three separate equations

:<math>
\begin{align}
x&=1+t\\
y&=1\\
z&=-2t.
\end{align}
</math>

If we use this for the equation of the plane, we get

:<math>
\begin{align}
x+y+z&=2\\
1+t+1-2t&=2\\
-t&=0
\end{align}
</math>

and therefore we conclude that t=0.  We plug this value of ''t'' back into the equation of the line to get that the point on the line that intersects the plane is (1,1,0).
statement_html:
Find the intersection of the line L and the plane P given below

\[\begin{aligned} L: & \quad \mathbf{x} = (1,1,0) + t(1,0,-2) \\ P: & \quad x + y + z = 2\end{aligned}\]
